abstract.t: On network links where the return capacity is much less than the forward capacity, acknowledgments of data receipt can reduce the efficient use of link capacity. Reducing the ratio of acknowledgements to data can help to improve link utilization. This document describes a modification to how frequently the QUIC transport protocol acknowledges the receipt of data.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document proposes increasing the ratio of ACK packets to data packets from 2:1 to 10:1 for QUIC flows once the flow has exited slow start. The increase in ACK ratio is proposed to not be more aggressive than the TCP Initial Window (IW) suggested by RFC6928 . The change in ACK ratio is proposed to improve return link efficiency on paths with highly asymmetric capacities.

RFC 5681 clarifies the ACKing frequency described in RFC 1122 to say that TCP implementations should ACK every second data segment when there is a steady stream of data. Sending fewer than 1 ACK for each data segment is called using an ACK delay. ACK delays helps to reduce return traffic and can increase network efficiency. However, if a sender does not send an ACK for every second segment a stretch ACK violation might occur. RFC2525 describes the significance of stretch ACK violations:

"TCP receivers exhibiting this behavior will cause TCP senders to generate burstier traffic, which can degrade performance in congested environments. In addition, generating fewer ACKs increases the amount of time needed by the slow start algorithm to open the congestion window to an appropriate point, which diminishes performance in environments with large bandwidth-delay products. Finally, generating fewer ACKs may cause needless retransmission timeouts in lossy environments, as it increases the possibility that an entire window of ACKs is lost, forcing a retransmission timeout."
Any ACKing scheme that increases the ACK ratio beyond 2 needs to compensate for these possible issues.
When network links have highly asymmetric capacities (such as in Cellular, DOCSYS cable or satellite networks) a high proportion of the opportunities to send might be used for purely ACK traffic.
This document suggests a modification to the ACK ratio for steady data streams and provides the considerations required to implement a higher ACK ratio safely.

section.title: Implications of Return Path Asymmetry
section.t: The TCP Performance Implications RFC describes a series of problems and mitigations from using an asymmetric path. Performance problems arise in several access networks, including bandwidth-asymmetric networks (such as broadband satellite access, DOCSIS cable networks, cellular mobile, etc), where a limited ACK rate results in constraining the throughput on both forward and return paths. This is a significant factor for paths with a capacity asymmetry greater than approx 1:40 (one ACK per TCP Segment).

Where the ACK rate is limited by the capacity of the return path this motivates the need to scale the ACK rate, or increase the number of segments/packets that are acknowledged by each ACK packet. Historically, "stretch ACKs" (an ACK that covers multiple received segments) have been considered to be an undesirable network pathology, because they can result in bursts of transmission. The use of ACK Thinning (deleting some TCP ACKs within a PEP device,) will lead to reception of Stretch ACKs (that cover more than one TCP MSS of data). An alternative is to either compress the ACKs on the radio segment or to reconstruct the ACK stream in a PEP after the radio segment.

Capacity is not the only asymmetric path constraint. In some network technologies (e.g., return link RRM allocation in a satellite BoD system, or an LTE scheduler in mobile) the transmission of ACKs across a network segment can also consume significant resource and therefore the cost to the user/operator of the network segment. This provides an incentive to reduce rate (or volume) of ACK traffic.

Reducing the rate of ACKs can also benefit wired scenarios by reducing the computational effort required to process ACKs and the rate of cache ejection for Generic Receiver Offload (GRO), both important in optimising network interfaces for high speed networks.
